Michael Pollan wrote a book about making a writing cabin called A Place of My Own: The Education of an Amateur Builder. It was published by Random House in New York in 1997. 

If you want to know more about William Shockley and how he created the junction transistor, check out the PBS article “Shockley Invents the Junction Transistor.” You can find it at http://www.pbs.org/transistor/background1/events/junctinv.html. 

There’s a blog post by Peter Shankman titled “‘Ohh! Shiny!’ DNA” on his website from July 2, 2014. You can read it at http://shankman.com/where-s-your-home/. 

In an interview with Shankman, it was mentioned that “The trip cost $4,000.” You can find this in Dyan Machan’s article “Why Some Entrepreneurs Call ADHD a Superpower” on MarketWatch from July 12, 2011, at http://www.marketwatch.com/story/entrepreneurs-superpower-for-some-its-adhd-1310052627559. 

Don’t Work Alone

In a July 2013 article from Bloomberg Businessweek by Venessa Wong called “Ending the Tyranny of the Open-Plan Office,” you can learn about how open office spaces can hurt worker productivity. The article is available at http://www.bloomberg.com/articles/2013-07-01/ending-the-tyranny-of-the-open-plan-office. 

The information about Facebook’s open office size, which has twenty-eight hundred workers, comes from a March 2014 Daily Mail article by Mark Prigg titled “Now That’s an Open Plan Office.” You can read it at http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2584738/Now-THATS-open-plan-office-New-pictures-reveal-Facebooks-hacker-campus-house-10-000-workers-ONE-room.html. 

Maria Konnikova wrote in The New Yorker about how open offices are supposed to “facilitate communication and idea flow” in her article “The Open-Office Trap” from January 7, 2014. You can find it at http://www.newyorker.com/business/currency/the-open-office-trap. 

Seth Stevenson said in Slate that “Open plan is pretty spectacular” in his article “The Boss with No Office” from May 4, 2014. You can check it out at http://www.slate.com/articles/business/psychology_of_management/2014/05/open_plan_offices_the_new_trend_in_workplace_design.1.html. 

Jack Dorsey mentioned “We encourage people to stay out in the open” in an article by Eric Savitz in Forbes on October 17, 2012. You can read it at http://www.forbes.com/sites/ericsavitz/2012/10/17/jack-dorsey-the-leadership-secrets-of-twitter-and-square/3/. 

The New Yorker has quotes about Building 20, along with some background and lists of inventions, from a 2012 article by Jonah Lehrer called “Groupthink.” You can find it at http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/01/30/groupthink. 

For info on Mervin Kelly and his goals for Bell Labs’s Murray Hill campus, check out Jon Gertner’s article “True Innovation” in the New York Times from February 25, 2012, at http://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/26/opinion/sunday/innovation-and-the-bell-labs-miracle.html. 

If you want a good summary of the history of the transistor, look at “Transistorized!” on PBS’s website at http://www.pbs.org/transistor/album1/. For a more detailed history, check out Chapter 7 of Walter Isaacson’s 2014 book, The Innovators, published by Simon and Schuster in New York. 

Execute Like a Business

To find out “How do I do this?” check pages xix–xx of The 4 Disciplines of Execution by Chris McChesney, Sean Covey, and Jim Huling, published by Simon and Schuster in New York in 2004. 

Clayton Christensen also talks about his experience with Andy Grove in a July–August 2010 Harvard Business Review article called “How Will You Measure Your Life?” He later expanded this into a book. 

**PAGE SUMMARY:** This passage includes references to various articles and books about topics like open office spaces, the invention of the transistor, and execution in business. It highlights the impact of work environments on productivity and shares insights from notable authors and entrepreneurs.
